sodium.options.view_distance.tooltip: The render distance controls how far away terrain will be rendered. Shorter distances mean that less terrain will be displayed, improving frame rates.
sodium.options.simulation_distance.toolt: The simulation distance controls how far away terrain and entities will be loaded and updated. Shorter distances can reduce the internal server's load and may improve frame rates.
sodium.options.brightness.tooltip: Controls the minimum brightness in the world. When increased, darker areas of the world will appear brighter. This does not affect the brightness of already well-lit areas.
sodium.options.gui_scale.tooltip: Sets the maximum scale factor to be used for the user interface. If 'auto' is selected, then the largest scale factor will always be applied.
sodium.options.fullscreen.tooltip: If enabled, the game will be displayed in full-screen mode (if supported).
sodium.options.fullscreen_resolution.too:
The monitor resolution and refresh rate to be used when in full-screen mode. Changing this option may interfere with other applications and cause a delay when switching between applications.

This is only supported on the Windows operating system.
sodium.options.v_sync.tooltip: If enabled, the game's frame rate will be synchronised to the monitor's refresh rate, providing a generally smoother experience at the expense of increased input latency. This setting might reduce performance if your system is too slow.
sodium.options.fps_limit.tooltip: Limits the maximum number of frames per second. This can help reduce battery usage and system load when multi-tasking. If VSync is enabled, this option will be ignored unless it is lower than your display's refresh rate.
sodium.options.view_bobbing.tooltip: If enabled, the player's view will sway and bob when moving around. Players who experience motion sickness while playing may benefit from disabling this.
sodium.options.attack_indicator.tooltip: Controls where the Attack Indicator is displayed on the screen.
sodium.options.autosave_indicator.toolti: If enabled, an indicator will be shown when the game is saving the world to disk.
sodium.options.graphics_quality.tooltip: The default graphics quality controls some legacy options and is necessary for mod compatibility. If the options below are left to "Default", they will use this setting.
sodium.options.clouds_quality.tooltip: The quality level used for rendering clouds in the sky. Although the options are labelled "Fast" and "Fancy", the effect on performance is negligible.
sodium.options.weather_quality.tooltip: Controls the distance that weather effects, such as rain and snow, will be rendered.
sodium.options.leaves_quality.name: Leaves
sodium.options.leaves_quality.tooltip: Controls whether leaves will be rendered as transparent (fancy) or opaque (fast).
sodium.options.particle_quality.tooltip: Controls the maximum number of particles which can be present on the screen at any one time.
sodium.options.smooth_lighting.tooltip: Enables the smooth lighting and shading of blocks in the world. This can slightly increase the amount of time it takes to load or update a chunk, but it doesn't affect frame rates.
sodium.options.biome_blend.tooltip: The distance (in blocks) over which biome colours are smoothly blended. Using higher values will greatly increase the amount of time it takes to load or update chunks, for diminishing improvements in quality.
sodium.options.entity_distance.tooltip: The render distance multiplier used by entity rendering. Smaller values decrease, and larger values increase, the maximum distance at which entities will be rendered.
sodium.options.entity_shadows.tooltip: If enabled, basic shadows will be rendered beneath mobs and other entities.
sodium.options.vignette.name: Vignette
sodium.options.vignette.tooltip: If enabled, a vignette effect will be applied when the player is in darker areas, making the overall image darker and more dramatic.
sodium.options.mipmap_levels.tooltip: Controls the number of mipmaps which will be used for block model textures. Higher values provide better rendering of blocks in the distance but may negatively affect performance with resource packs that use many animated textures.
sodium.options.use_block_face_culling.to: If enabled, only the faces of blocks which are facing the camera will be submitted for rendering. This can eliminate a large number of block faces very early in the rendering process, greatly improving rendering performance. Some resource packs may have issues with this option, so try disabling it if you see holes in blocks.
sodium.options.use_fog_occlusion.name: Use Fog Occlusion
sodium.options.use_fog_occlusion.tooltip: If enabled, chunks which are completely obscured by fog effects will not be rendered, helping to improve performance. The improvement can be more significant when fog effects are heavier (such as while underwater), but it may cause undesirable visual artefacts between the sky and fog in some scenarios.
sodium.options.use_entity_culling.name: Use Entity Culling
sodium.options.use_entity_culling.toolti: If enabled, entities which are within the camera's view but not inside a visible chunk will be skipped during rendering. This optimisation uses the visibility data which already exists for chunk rendering and does not add extra overhead.
sodium.options.animate_only_visible_text: If enabled, only the animated textures which are visible in the current image will be updated. This can provide a significant performance improvement on some hardware, especially with heavy resource packs. If you encounter issues with some textures not animating, try disabling this option.
sodium.options.cpu_render_ahead_limit.to: For debugging only. Specifies the maximum number of frames which can be in-flight to the GPU. Changing this value is not recommended, as very low or high values may create frame rate instability.
sodium.options.use_persistent_mapping.to:
For debugging only. If enabled, persistent memory mappings will be used for the staging buffer to avoid unnecessary memory copies. Disabling this can help in narrowing down the cause of graphical corruption.

Requires OpenGL 4.4 or ARB_buffer_storage.
sodium.options.chunk_update_threads.name: Chunk Update Threads
sodium.options.chunk_update_threads.tool: Specifies the number of threads to use for chunk building and sorting. Using more threads can speed up chunk loading and update times, but may negatively affect frame consistency. The default value is usually sufficient.
sodium.options.always_defer_chunk_update: If enabled, rendering will never wait for chunk updates to complete, even if they are important. This can significantly improve frame rates in some cases, but may cause noticeable visual lag where blocks take time to appear or disappear.
sodium.options.sort_behavior.name: Translucency Sorting
sodium.options.sort_behavior.tooltip: Enables translucency sorting. This avoids glitches in translucent blocks like water and glass when enabled and aims to present them correctly, even when the camera is moving. This has a small performance impact on chunk loading and update speeds, but it is usually not noticeable in frame rates.
sodium.options.use_no_error_context.name: Use No Error Context
sodium.options.use_no_error_context.tool: When enabled, the OpenGL context will be created without error checking. This slightly improves rendering performance but can make debugging unexpected crashes more difficult.
sodium.console.game_restart: The game must be restarted to apply one or more video settings!
sodium.console.broken_nvidia_driver:
Your NVIDIA graphics drivers are out of date!
  * This will cause severe performance issues and crashes when Sodium is installed.
  * Please update your graphics drivers to the latest version (version 536.23 or newer).
sodium.console.pojav_launcher:
PojavLauncher is not supported when using Sodium.
  * You are likely to encounter severe performance issues, graphical bugs, and crashes.
  * You will be on your own if you decide to proceed -- we will not assist with any bugs or crashes!
sodium.console.core_shaders_error: The following resource packs are incompatible with Sodium:
sodium.console.core_shaders_unsupported:
The installed OpenGL drivers do not support the minimum requirements for Sodium's internal shaders.
  * Please update your graphics drivers and try again, or disable the "Default" shaders for an alternative look.
